body:
>>  I don't know what you mean, but Go doesn't have classes.

Yes, I know. Classes means a `virtual` and `abstract` methods.
Go does not have them.
But Go has other concepts and one of them is `concept of receivers` (you know what I mean).
If any `type` can have a `set of methods` related to it then why did not allow (not force, in any case) to declare some part of this `set of methods` all togheter in a some grouped form of shortened declaration?
Benefits:
1. Less code. The (`func receiver`) always omitted which means we are inside a `parenthesized method declarations` of some type
2. Grouping (by some reason, in some place)
3. Not need to warry about `receiver` specifying each time when you add a new method inside such `block` only because you already specify it (once) in the `header` of parenthesized method declarations.
